reviewText:
Early Access Review

If the game has the full features of the real Ninja Fruits, then it's worth $15 or more...but it's not. You got a single repetitive sword slashing with no variety in game play.  Although it looks like a polished game and comes with high quality graphics and leaderboards, it's not a finish product and certainly not warrant $15.  I'll give it a second look when the finish product come out. Basically, I am not betting my money on it even though it's an early access.  Games like Brookhaven however, I would not hesitate to buy it because I know what to expect in the finished product. Not this game..

This release should have been a demo for now. It's just not finished.
voteText: 36 of 55 people (65%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ZenBlade is an addicting casual VR game that resembles Fruit Ninja! It is currently in early access.

Check out my Quick Preview here: https://youtu.be/SDIjbFyeogk
I played the ZenBlade using the HTC Vive, and I felt like fruit and bombs are really flying at me, and I don’t know why, but I kept trying to jump away from the bombs even though they don’t hurt me.

There are two modes available. In timed mode, you play on a timer, and as the clock starts ticking down, you aim to get the highest score by slicing as much fruit as you can. In survival mode, you can’t let the fruit drop, when three fruit hit the floor, you lose. Slicing more fruit in one swing awards bonus points, but if you hit the bombs, you lose points!

I really love the sword mechanics! You have to swing hard enough to slice the fruit, and swing from the right angle. You can also knock bombs away with the hilt of the sword, and juggle fruit off the sides of the blade to set yourself up for better combos.

Pros:even in early access, the game is pretty polished
the room scaling is done very well - I had zero nausea!
moving around, and swinging the sword feels very natural - the sword play is very responsive, and extremely fun to use
the haptic feedback makes it feel like you’re actually slicing through the fruit
addictive gameplay, that is easy to learn, and fun for the whole family
taking turns and competing with friends locally is fun
Cons:repetitive gameplay that can get boring, especially if you're playing alone
lacks content, there are only two modes available, but I expect more to be added before full release
no way to keep track of players top scores while playing locally with friends (maybe an option to save scores with initials could be added)
Playing Zenblade is addictive as you compete to get better scores. It is still in early access though, so I’d still like to see more modes added, maybe some where the fruit comes in from other directions, or fruit comes endlessly until you hit a certain number of bombs or a mode where you have to dodge the bombs before they kill you. Or maybe even something where armored fruit enemies come at you from all directions and you have to slice and stab them where they are vulnerable. Now that would be awesome!

So far, I’ve been playing with others for over 4 hours, and even though I’m absolutely terrible at the game, I’m still enjoying it. ZenBlade has a lot of potential, and I look forward to seeing what they do with it before the full release. Since I have been playing with others, I am satisfied with the purchase. But, if I had intended to play alone, I would have waited for more content to be added or a slight sale price.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is quite addictive and the physics is nice although you cannot thrust the sword in the fruits, and the fruits behave a bit too much as beach balls when struck. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: Early access in the first build. I'll make an effort to update this as the development progress

This game is a lot of fun and it's very addictive. It has that effect of making you want to play just one more and beat your high score. In fact, I set some ice cream out to soften it and figured I'd play a couple rounds of this while it sat. 40 minutes later I came out and the ice cream was soup lol. The sword physics and the graphics are great. This has the potential to be THE VR sword game.

BUT, it's not quite there yet. What is there is polished and well done, but maybe not $15 of fun. If the devs are speaking the truth and willing to put some work in on this I think it easily could be, but at the moment I'd have to advise waiting a couple of weeks and seeing how the game progresses in that time. I'm willing to jump in early and back them personally, but early access is a gamble so consider that before you buy.

Early Access Review

The game is highly polished and great fun.

What is there is a simple but highly addictive and fun experience with some excellent sword swinging mechanics.

The devs are taking time to engage with the community on this one as I feel this could turn out to be one of the best VR games available for the Vive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just one more round I thought! This round will be the one!
Nope. So Then I played it again and again.
You can play it just 2 minutes, but it's hard to quit till you get a good round  & workout.

I bring this game out at all my demos. It's a good use of room size, and definitely the direction I want to see VR swordplay headed.  It's super good for beginners, but the skill ceiling is high. My top scores so far are 477, 336, and 330. Average is around 180. The current fruit distribution is random, some times are better than others, but if you get in the zone and connect your slices in a big swooping arc, you can get huge combos. They're one of those video game memory making moments.

For a while I was annoyed by the tiny fruit, but I got better at the game, and can slice it like mad.

Also, there are leaderboards (daily + all time) so you don't have to try to beat an insanely lucky person, just the best score of the day.

Also, I hear you can turn off the music with M" so you can jam with your own tunes and try to slice to the beat. =)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, so this is an EA review and will be reviewed in it's current state as well as what's to come as described in the Q&A.

This game is fun, for a few minutes. You'll come back to it again and again, for a few minutes. This game definitely has that awesome replayability factor going for it but needs more content and depth to keep you engaged for longer than a game or two at a time. The new survival mode is definitely a step in the right direction, as you can keep going indefinitely if you're good enough, but without a variety of game modes this falls a bit short.

Is it worth the price? Maybe. I would say it's currently worth about 10 dollars as the available content is a lot of fun, but a bit shallow. However, the developers state the price will not change after release and if so then I believe it will be worth it and more as soon as the developers flesh the game out a bit more.

And please devs, make updates available on your store page, I found out about the survival update in the Discussions and it wasn't even stickied!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes this is basically fruit ninja in VR however that really doesn't do the game justice. I think the only negative with the game is the price. The sword action is extremely accurate which gets me really excited about potential for sword fighting Vive games. This is a nice and easy game that can be played by anyone in your family and a good game to show to non-gamer friends. However, it's also surprisingly addictive for gamers as well.

There are two modes - 1) Time Mode where you have 1 minute to score as many points as possible (additional points for slicing 2, 3, or 4 fruits with one stroke, -10 points for hitting bombs) or 2) Survival mode where you keep getting points until you either hit a bomb or let 3 fruits fall down without being sliced. The leaderboards make an excellent motivator to keep trying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun game, but it really needs more content the current gamemodes are very similar and get repetative pretty quick.
Unlockable sword designs would be a pretty cool idea.
The only other issue I have with the game is that the sword doesn't always seem to cut consistently, I'll chop 3 fruit in a row and the first/last will be cut in half and the middle one will be sent flying across the room as if I hit it with the blunt end. Other times the sword will just phase straight through.

I hope the devs add a lot more content and clean up the glitches as it could be a really good purchase.
